Articles.Content: You've only yourself to blame for actually reading youtube comments.

I like the analogy of this mission and missions like it to the building of the medieval cathedrals in Europe. Projects literally take decades to plan, execute and analyze. The real world isn't KSP. Pulling this off in the real world is a remarkable achievement.

Youtube is exploding with comments that the lack of pictures must mean it is a hoax and that people are busy Photoshopping as we speak. We not only learn about comets, but also about human stupidity

http://xkcd.com/202/

youtube comments are baaaad ;-)

First pics coming in....

hehehe

You've only yourself to blame for actually reading youtube comments.

TouchÃƒÂ©.

(Fair enough, for those that struggle with foreign languages )
Amazing achievement. Glad to be around and hear about it live! Well done ESA! Looking forward to hear about the discoveries!
go europe!

What I caught of the update by Kuhn Gertz in Koln, the harpoons and the landing thrusters didn't fire so it may not actually be down solidly on the surface. They are considering trying the harpoons/landing screws again.

The landing legs only compressed by 4 cm, which is less than expected.
Seems like thruster did not fire (problem with it was indicated earlier on), and sadly: telemetry indicates anchors didn't fire either, though this will require further confirmation.
The man in the live stream says harpoons have been fired and rewound, so what is the story?
Yes but later another man said that they didn't fire and they were thinking about trying to fire them again...

The man in the live stream says harpoons have been fired and rewound, so what is the story?

I wondered that too, does that mean it's now tethered?

The man in the live stream says harpoons have been fired and rewound, so what is the story?

Fired, rewound, without sticking into the ground.

Seems like thruster did not fire (problem with it was indicated earlier on), and sadly: telemetry indicates anchors didn't fire either, though this will require further confirmation.

A guy from the mission control was just doing a recap for BBC, the harpoons did not fire and neither did the thruster. He said it was a very soft landing, as the probe bounced up only 4 cm, but they cannot confirm that they are firmly standing/attached on the surface. He said they are moving some instruments on the probe, which makes it move about a little.

Edit: and apparently I misheard or something, according to the post above... Still very exciting. With any luck, people will be making conspiracy theories about today in 40 years time.

Edited November 12, 2014 by Torham234

French ESA tweet : further analysis show that harpoons were in fact not fired. Otherwise, Philae is in very good shape.

Big Congratulations!

Edited November 12, 2014 by LoggerM

Philae after release on it's way down to 67P.

Ninja'd!

Edited November 12, 2014 by Excalibur
Ninja'd

With any luck, people will be making conspiracy theories about today in 40 years time.

40 years? Try today. People were, like posted before, already talking about how the pictures are taking too long and that this must mean Photoshop work is being done. As if that was not done in advance if it would all be an elaborate hoax.
In the live stream at 3:37:20, the guy says the harpoons did not fire.

nice, first comet landing, done! +300 science

they didn't even forgot the landing lags or the solar panels
Apparently, no harpoons attached, and no thruster. They're considering whether or not to manually fire the harpoons. A bit of a risky move I guess, but it may not be secured otherwise

they didn't even forgot the landing lags or the solar panels

I'd hate to be the PR manager for the Kerbal space program.

"Landing legs operated perfectly but we put them on upside down, so, uh. Questions?"

Apparently, no harpoons attached, and no thruster. They're considering whether or not to manually fire the harpoons. A bit of a risky move I guess, but it may not be secured otherwise

It'd be terrible to push your lander off by trying to fix it. All I can say is Hang on, little guy.
Uh, Harvester? SQUAD? Can we have a comet in KSP? Even one? Pretty plllleeeeaaasseeee???
Well as long as the comet doesn't become active and starts expelling gas, I guess Philae isn't going anywhere..
